Output Indicator 1: Rapid assessment of socio-economic impact completed. To understand the full socio-economic impact of COVID-19 on vulnerable groups, UNDP conducted surveys at the mahalla (community) and businesses levels, in coordination with the Ministry of Mahalla and Family Support (the MMFS). The reports have been finalized, the business survey provided important data on the lockdown’s impact for business performance and the restructuring of business activities, and this has already informed the government’s latest business relief measures.
Output Indicator 2: Early recovery interventions targeting most vulnerable groups: As technical lead of the UN system in the response, UNDP and the WB coordinated the Multilateral COVID-19 Socio Economic Response and Recovery Offer for Uzbekistan. UNDP has worked with ILO, UNICEF and other agencies to ensure alignment between poverty reduction (supported by UNDP and WB) and social protection strategy (supported by ILO and UNICEF). Under this output both international and local consultants have been recruited. The business clinic programme was recalibrated to focus webinars, Q&A sessions, hotline consultations, and information materials in supporting SMEs generate early recovery strategies. At the time of reporting, approximately 15,000 representatives of SMEs have benefited from these resources, made available through partnerships with leading online and TV business channels MFaktor and UzReport, and the high profile contribution of prominent business leaders.
In order to ensure that the short- term emergency employment interventions explicitly include skills training and that they meet long-term community infrastructure development needs UNDP has created 250 vocational training videos in partnership with the Ministry of Employment and Labour Relations.
UNDP also launched the COVID-19 IT Challenge 2020 to help identify innovative solutions for mitigating the pandemic’s community impacts through entrepreneurship. After more than 600 applications- with over 130 from teams of women- a total of 110 proposal teams were interviewed online, and 12 semi-finalists identified. Participants were encouraged to open source their submissions to share and promote their innovation with the greater community. Following another round of interviews, the 5 most promising projects were selected and awarded a maximum of US $10,000, with support of the Ministry for Innovative Development and Youth Union, to test and deploy their proposals.
Output Indicator 3: Strengthening employment capacity of the women-led households in Syrdarya region: The preliminary list of women-led businesses, and the specialized equipment they need for procurement, has been identified · The procurement of sewing machines and furniture for training centers has started; and tools for the sewing workshop (overlock machine, sewing and cutting machine, steam generator, wet/heat treatment plants, machine, tossing loops, cutting machines ax) have been approved. · Sewing machines, devices for tailoring, and hair salon are being procured, and pasta production equipment is being reviewed. 1b) Organization of a handicrafts training center for women: · The 300 sq. m training facility has been negotiated and secured, along with agreement on required furnishings, with Ministry of Mahalla and Family Affairs partner. · The ToR for center training team has been developed.
Output Indicator 3: Strengthening employment capacity of the women-led households in Syrdarya region. Indicators • At least 100 jobs for women are created. • At least 1,500 unemployed women
